job_title: Marketing and Communications Lead in Fort Collins, CO
pros: CSU can be a great place to work, but this largely depends on your division, job, and manager/director. I have worked for very kind, supportive, professional, and capable people (including my current manager). I have also worked for very burned-out people, and in one case, a complete tyrant (not my direct supervisor, thankfully). On average, most people are very professional, supportive, and skilled -- and we do try to have fun occasionally.
cons: Overall, the university is "committed" to principles of "inclusion, integrity, respect, service and social justice." However, in practice, this is not always the case. The people in high-level leadership positions are often extremely out of touch with what's happening at lower levels of the org. Our division has experienced major instability of leadership for years, churning through multiple associate provosts, senior directors, and at least one VP (not including the P resigning during that time and numerous interim leaders that have come and gone). The HR department experiences constant churn (can't imagine why), and the hiring process is byzantine and slow. The uni also does not pay admin professionals competitively, with salaries and job classifications all over the map. Most people in my division do not last more than a few years before moving on. CSU could be a fantastic place to work, but it will take a lot more effort and resources.

review_title: Relaxed Work Environment doling out Valuable Experience
job_title: Driver in Fort Collins, CO
pros: This is actually a fun job. You pick up the stuff, sort the stuff, put the good stuff out for sale, and smash the bad stuff with a sledge hammer to recycle or throw away. You can tailor your schedule to your classes and Jake encourages you to take hour lunches. Jake really understands the lives of working students and Lino really tries to help accommodate all types of schedules with the way he runs the truck routes. You'll gain valuable practical skills in forklifting, truck driving, inventory systems, appraising retail items, recycling procedures, etc. A low pressure setting where accidents are learning experiences not excuses to mock or punish. I'm leaving after two school years and my experience has secured me a great job at another large university. Not a mistake to work here. ANY MAJOR can find valuable experience here. Sustainability majors can learn about recycling and reuse, compsci students can gain experience testing, repairing and scrapping a wide array of tech, Business majors will gain experience in asset management/inventory systems, Heck even Fashion majors would love to sort through vintage lost and found clothing to update their wardrobe. The list goes on folks, work here and find your reason.
cons: Some lifting Sometimes you'll get a little dirty Make sure to wear gloves Driving a box truck on a campus of 25000 students on bikes and hoverboards can be daunting The pay structure is bound to the constraints of the student employee rules for the entire university. Not open on weekends? I personally loved weekends off but if you want extra hours they can only be picked up on school days

job_title: Office Manager in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Great people, flexible work schedule, beautiful campus, exciting research work
cons: Salary and benefits are subpar compared to other universities. CSU has a problem of overworking and underpaying their staff. This is a university-wide issue, which is why so many people have left. Everyone carries at least double (if not more) the workload than they should, they work on vacations and work tons of OT, and the only relief is to quit because there isn't enough money to hire the amount of staff that they actually need. It's also impossible to fire employees that are underperforming or are conflictual, and its driving the younger generation out because we don't want to work in a place with zero accountability.

review_title: Absolutely horrid response to covid and racial bias incidents on campus.
job_title: Technician in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Very laid-back work most environment of the time. On-campus amenities are nice (outside of campus): gym, pool, intramural fields, rock climbing gym, etc
cons:
Our team has consistently reached out to leadership asking for help or allowances to hold students accountable for lack of adherence to covid protocols with no real help. 
HR is constantly behind on paperwork, even before covid. 
Our CEO consistently ignores the requests and advice given during representative council meetings from our diverse students. 
There is a good handful of staff in various departments that are active climate change deniers, not to mention ones taken away from primary class teaching due to racial bias incidents, where upper management's ultimate excuse is "we can't do anything, they're tenured". 
Even at 20% capacity during AY2021, parking services have ticketed nearly 6000 vehicles. 
The only department that feels fully supported and staffed appropriately is the Athletics department that barely carries its own weight, and was recently served three different cases of racial bias and insensitivity, especially towards students of color.
Many of the on-campus awards for staff do nothing more than mention them in a newsletter.
Waited until Colorado was already an outbreak state before going remote.

review_title: Excellent at higher levels. Not so much for the lower echelon.
job_title: Content Marketing Strategist in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Working for CSU in the Extended Campus division (CSU Online) over the past four years has been good overall. The vast majority of people I've worked with have been outstanding colleagues. The work environment in my division has improved significantly in recent years following a change in leadership. CSU has very good PTO benefits (you accumulate two days of paid leave every month as an admin pro). Generous paid sick leave. Pretty good 401K. Flexible work schedule (depending on your department and supervisor). Standard 40-hour work week. Remote work has been normalized during the pandemic, and will likely retain wider acceptance when things "return to normal." CSU prides itself on treating employees fairly and creating an equitable, inclusive, and safe workplace. You do not have to worry about being fired just because your supervisor doesn't like you, which is huge.
cons: Working in higher ed takes some getting used to. There is a hefty amount of bureaucracy to contend with, depending on your division and role. However, this bureaucracy exists primarily to ensure the University operates in an ethical, fiscally responsible, and sustainable way (or at least that's the intent). Tenured faculty hold a considerable amount of power and influence, too much in some cases. There are some very large egos among tenured faculty, but also some incredible educators and researchers. It's a mixed bag. Sadly, adjunct faculty are still significantly underpaid and undervalued, which is the case across all of higher ed. As a staff member, there is NOT a lot of opportunity for upward mobility. People in mid-level and especially higher-level positions tend to stay in them for a long time, because the pay and benefits are so good. There is much more frequent turnover among lower-level positions, many of which don't pay very well compared to similar jobs in a corporate environment. Annual salary increases for staff (when they happen) are generally very modest, regardless of work performance. The university lacks a good system to reward and/or promote (and ultimately retain) its most talented staff.

job_title: Information Technology Professional in Fort Collins, CO
pros: The benefits.  The Colorado PERA retirements package is great, and the Long Term Disability is a great insurance to have in case you become disabled.  The package is not as good as it was, but it still beats social security and medicare.  The hours are pretty standard, making it a great place to work if you place an emphasis on family time.  And then there's Fort Collins, which is a wonderful place to live.
cons:
It's still a very conservative place to work.  Some departments are better than others.  But there are certainly plenty of departments with a lack of diversity and a plethora of middle-aged WASP's.  Management is generally not supportive and tolerant of diversity.  HR does little to remedy this, and the OEO is a joke.

The technology is a little antiquated, which is what you would expect from a government institution.  The furniture is at least 20-30 years old in my department, and the pace of work is ssllllooowwww.  If a corporation were run this way, they'd never stay in business.  Still, it does provide for a less stressful work environment, even if it is demoralizing and demotivating.

Promotions are given to favorites, so don't expect your job title or duties to change without switching departments.

job_title: Research Scientist in Fort Collins, CO
pros: The work enviroment at Colorado State is informal. Generally flex time allows you take care of emergencies. Fort Collins is an excellent place to live and has consistently been ranked as one of the top small cities to live in America. Houses are reasonable priced and there is a large park for kids within walking distance of your house. The public library is excellent. There are bike lanes on nearly every street and trails run through the city. The downtown has its own character and you could easily spend an evening just window shopping. The resources at CSU are generally sufficient to do your job. This includes the availability of journals, books and computing resources. Even though the rest of the benefits are not that great CSU provides 24 days of annual vacation from day 1. Can't beat that. Of course you can go skiing in winter and river rafting in summer on that vacation time.
cons: The benefits are not the greatest but Colorado State University is making an effort to improve that. The State has some issue with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights hampering higher education funding. Hopefully they will solve this problem soon. This city is not very big so employment is limited. So it would be better to get a job before you move to this city. The infrastructure at the University is suffering because of a shortfall in funding but the state has taken notice and will hopefully find some money to improve the classrooms and hire new faculty in some departments with high enrollment.

review_title: Great place to work for paycheck
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Great pay and benefits if you like working hard and are willing to cover for your boss since they are never around.
cons:
Ethics are not a top priority.  You put your neck and reputation on the line for the institution, the students and the university's public face but then have to suck it up and either live with the corruption, lies to both internal & external audiences, and the constant threat to your job if you do not play along.  

Took almost 2 years to get any of my retirement plan funds (401K and PERA) approved to transfer to another plan.  I applied for full retirement, which was approved, and left the organization after doing a whistle-blower action.  Found out 2 months later (after an audit initiated the day I left) that I was 2 days short of full retirement (after being told I was retired with full benefits) and that there was nothing they could do and they refused to rehire me for the 2 days.  This type of retaliation in the norm and they hide behind the state government rules to "make these issues go away".

job_title: Marketing and Web Coordinator in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Good benefits, flexible work schedules, and annual leave.
cons: Difficulty in changing jobs within the university.

job_title: Director of Outreach in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Coworkers are a pleasure to be around.
cons: Could see an increase in department management.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Good pay and good community
cons: No benefits and poor culture

job_title: Sales Representative in Denver, CO
pros: great company and atmosphere to work for
cons: student schedule for athletic marketing.

job_title: Front End Manager in Boca Raton, FL
pros: zero. No-one cares who works there , especially the owners
cons: job security is terrible. tHe absolute worst.

job_title: Lab Assistant II in Fort Collins, CO
pros:
Location (besides construction &parking)
Responsibility and independence to do your own work. Can make great connections in the department. You can take a lot of pride in your work since it's research and as an undergrad your not pressured to get results like the full time research assistants are. Schedule is make your own/very flexible. Working and going to school at the same time. 

The experience is great and an awesome resume builder. Some opportunities to be hired as full time after graduation
cons: Grant funded, hours can be lagging or demanding depending on the week. The pay scale doesn't really keep up with cost of living. I have friends making more money as college students elsewhere. Getting to CSU really sucks transportation wise. Some undergrads have been hired that turn out to be terrible workers but are never fired.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Collins, CO
pros: There might be a good department somewhere on campus, but most of the it departments are failing or treading water at best.
cons:
This is a government job and the pay is lagging behind the industry and doesn't look like that will change in the next 10 years. Because the pay is low you only get desperate candidates who cant get a job elsewhere.

In my specific department management is trying to eliminate technical staff, but have to higher more because people keep quitting before they can transition.

Technology is older and would be great for new projects except no one is interested in making anything better than as it already exists. Any new ideas get killed because no one wants to use their budget to do them. Everyone is compartmentalized and as a result the university buys several different software products to solve the same solution and no one will share their licenses. Departments charge other departments for their services which kills any collaboration.

job_title: Manager in Castle Rock, CO
pros: Good benefits, new leadership that's actually attempting to make a difference.
cons: Too traditional! CSU-Fort Collins positions silos that stifle innovation. More often than not, it is difficult for Administrators to cross-collaborate with other colleagues across institutional departments due to these silos.

review_title: Graduate school is a good career decision, but try to avoid getting into debt.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: A graduate degree in Computer Science will greatly enhance your employment prospects.. The professors are knowledgeable in their fields and generally give a lot of personal time to graduate students.  The University has a pleasant atmosphere and lots of amenities.
cons: Graduate school does not include competitive compensation in their package, and at CSU that includes health insurance and student fees, which will amount to 25-30% of your annual income.  You will have a hard time making ends meet on your stipend.  The quality of research is below that of big name schools and you are unlikely to get into the top conferences and journals unless you work in Atmospheric Science.

review_title: CSU best as a stepping stone, not good for long term job
job_title: Research Associate III in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Great vacation benefits (24 days a year) and that's about it.
cons: Constant budget insecurities at the state level make it so that the university continually gives only a 2% raise annually, an amount that is not keeping up with the cost of living along the front range. Bad national level funding for science makes temporal security of your job not great either. Bad policies by college directors and university leadership that favors professors at the expense of everyone else. Issues taking the great vacation benefits sometimes because of bad policies.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Very collaborative environment, with great research resources for biomedical engineering given the nationally leading Vet school at CSU. The biomedical engineering program is fantastic, with great classes overall, and a growing number of students and faculty. The school is largely independent of state funding, and brings in a large amount of research and philanthropic money. Plus, Fort Collins is a great city to live in.
cons: Standard academic politics do apply somewhat, though I believe it is better than many places. As always, specific experience will largely be determined by your student-advisor relationship. Student funding is largely on a cases-by-case basis, make sure you understand clearly what it will and won't include before you wind up in a financially dry spot.

review_title: Severely disorganized from top to bottom, with no organization or structure
job_title: DS III in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Decent benefits plan, HR makes extra effort to sort out any medical or work issues that may occur.
cons:
Lack of organization and leadership from top management on down.  No clear plans on how to achieve goals.  Management, with a few notable exceptions, engages in favoritism and petty office politics, actively seeks to sabotage efforts by workers either out of spite or incompetence.  Terrible morale is only accentuated by empty efforts on the part of management to bring in "motivational speakers" or forcing workers to engage in time and resource-wasting "group activities" that are allegedly team-building but are scheduled in such a way as to interfere with important events or daily work activities.

In short, again, with few notable exceptions, workers were constantly set up for failure.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Fort Collins, CO
pros: It was a very congenial place to work, but as soon as I was having a little trouble making it to a class, which could have been swapped with another prof, they laid me off that summer....no tenure. I had developed a neurological disease which effected my ability to move fast through crowded corridors. So, I was late (about 2 minutes) to class twice that semester.
cons: The leadership was very poor in the liberal arts department, and no room at all for anyone with a disability or getting a little older....over 50.

job_title: Adjunct; Administrator in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Good benefits, barely adequate compensation (4200 per course in liberal arts, 6000 per course in business assuming a PhD.), but dynamic and responsive work environment. Student body is getting better and the university continues to expand programmatic support for undergrads.
cons: Adjunct faculty get paid per course and the institution ups your enrollments every semester. Lots of students and raises are meager (1-1.5% per year). Had to move into administration to pay the bills but was still able to teach one a semester to supplement the income. Administrative compensation is poor in most colleges at the university (40-50K).

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: As a graduate student, their package for Graduate Teaching Assistants is pretty good, tuition is covered, and their health insurance plan is great, mostly free (you have to pay a little for the tax benefit) and their health center treats a lot of different issues and has an in house pharmacy, all of which don't cost you anything if you are on the health insurance plan. The stipend is low considering the cost of living in Fort Collins.
cons: Working in survey classes can be difficult, and students can easily get under your skin, if you let them. Also, some GTA's work more than others depending on the professor they are assigned to, so I feel like in a sense, we don't get paid equally for the amount of work we do.

review_title: Familiarize yourself with types of employment and associates benefits and compensation.
job_title: Information Technology in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Admin Pros get generous time off (24 days at time of hire) and depending on the college or department, may receive significant raises. State Classified employees are not employed at will.
cons: Admin Pros are employed at will which means you can get fired at the will of your supervisor. State Classified employees may or may not receive raises even for exemplary work as salaries are tied to the state budget (there were times when there were no raises for a few years in a row).

job_title: Coordinator in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Working at CSU, for one of the colleges provides some of the benefits of both a larger company and a smaller one.  The vacation time really stands out as a plus in the compensation package.  I would describe my experience at CSU as fairly laid back, but not without challenges and opportunities.
cons: In my college at least, we are growing to the point where we need to implement significantly more structure--this transition can be difficult for some.  The monetary compensation is not what I would call competitive, though there are tradeoffs.  Budgets have been tight with the economy, making raises and promotions difficult to come by.

review_title: The Engines Lab is a pretty great place to work. Especially for an undergad.
job_title: in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Working at the engines lab is first of all really great experience. There is huge flexibility on scheduling as they primarily employ students. The staff is very knowledgeable and you face new challenges everyday.
cons: There are a lot of times where you are given a task without much knowledge and told to "figure it out". This could be a good thing or a bad. It is often frustrating. Also the staff with most of the expertise is usually over burdened so it can be hard to get instruction sometimes.

review_title: Proud to be a working CSU Ram!
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Wonderful colleagues here that always want to help out and make sure you succeed.  The professionalism of everyone who works here is great to be a part of.  Everyone knows that there is one mission here and that is to have the students succeed.
cons: The slow pace of Academia creates problems sometimes.  If you want or need something very quickly there is normally many hoops to jump through to get there.  It is better to cover your bases and plan far ahead to make sure you have enough time to get everything done.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Hilo, HI
pros: Good benefits, tuition costs cover 9 credits a year. The pay is not the best for living in Hawaii but pays better that local agencies. I'm sorry I wish I had more positive things to say but I can't think of them. If you have the option of not taken this job DON'T TAKE IT. I was recruited over the phone, and I was not informed honestly on what was expected of my job.
cons: Management is poorly trained. I have a master's degree yet I find 8 hrs of my 40 working hours go to cleaning because the company doesn't hire maintenance people. Management is so rude to the employees, this drives the moral down around the peers. Supervisor are not trained in management and it really shows, most if not all supervisors are painfully ignorant at their job.

review_title: There are many types of employees
job_title: GIS Technician in Berthoud, CO
pros: The name means something to prospective employers and CSU contributes to a retirement account.  There are endless possibilities for future research projects which opens up lots of opportunity to learn.
cons: An hourly non-student employee does not receive health benefits or paid time off.  Parking is absolutely horrific.  Students, visitors, and employees all pay to park.  The parking police hand out tickets within minutes and there are 2 hour limits to park on campus.  If your job requires you to be on campus, your best bet is parking far away and busing in.

review_title: Exciting place to work, but always chasing funding.
job_title: Research Associate III in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Loved the research teams I worked with, very smart people and welcoming. Entrepreneurial environment, great professors that have their fingers in all kinds of pies.
cons: As a Research Associate, you are constantly on the pitch for funding to keep your job. Mine lasted about 18-mo, which was wonderful while it lasted, but I finally had to throw in the towel and go back to the private sector.

job_title: Adjunct Teaching in Fort Collins, CO
pros: good benefits, decent salary, some people are okay, but usually stay in their academic back-ground to make friends.
cons: Very biased towards age and handicap. I traveled 2000 miles for this job, and they laid me off after one year because I was late to class twice. They knew I had a handicap and would not go so far as to put my class in the same building as I was, which was very easy to do as other English classes were already using that room.

job_title: Program Assistant II in Fort Collins, CO
pros: I was able to obtain my degree while working full time.  CSU has helped me develop many skill sets and I have been able to change departments for different opportunities.
cons: The benefits packages just aren't what they used to be.  And sometimes it's easy to get stuck in a rut.  Also because it's a governmental entity, the work spaces are typically substandard and many building have been condemned but are still allowed to be used because of the governmental status.  Tenured faculty are treated as royalty even though they may be a pain in the behind.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Great place to learn and teach. It is specially a great opportunity to improve oneself. The professor I worked for was great, very considerate about my own class and exams.
cons: The only problem I can think of is, the number of students. If you are working for one of the elective courses there are many students. In my case over 130 students in two sections. so It may feel overwhelming sometimes. Specially during the exam weeks.

job_title: Morgan Library Supervisor in Fort Collins, CO
pros: It is a great place to work because you are generally working with students so they are open-minded and geared to learning.
cons: There is currently a pay raise lock as the school is not receiving enough funding.  In tough times the university suffers because the state cannot provide further funding.

job_title: Student Custodian in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Working in Environmental Services was a great job to have during the school year, being both flexible and relatively high paying. In addition, there was the opportunity for summer employment through this position, which I took.
cons: There was a great deal of monotony for the job, and waking up earlier in the mornings during the summer was a great downside. I would say that later hours during the summer by just an hour or two would greatly increase my satisfaction for this job.

review_title: Work environment is flexible and Fort Collins is a nice place to live in
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: The research environment is very flexible. People in the department  are friendly. Good facility and experiment equipments in the clean room.
cons: Fort Collins is a relatively small town, majority of the population here are students or stuff / faculties in CSU, so if you like the life in big city, like new york, this is not the good place for you.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: It has been a great learning experience so far and I enjoy what I am doing. Interacting with students and sharing advice with them makes me more confident of my skills and my knowledge.
cons: Sometimes, it gets hard to communicate with professors and understand what they really want me to do. Often, students do not follow instructions and make my life harder.

job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Retirement contributions for postdocs, beautiful surroundings, proximity to outdoor activities
cons: cost of living, inflexible live/work arrangements as a result of cost of living, fact that CSU will DEFINITELY pay you less because they figure in the desire to be here as a valuable benefit.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Fort Collins, CO
pros: The faculty that are there are for the most part great and working towards an innovative and engaging program
cons: Budgets of some colleges and departments is limited and creates difficulty in creating a robust program. Some departments are understaffed putting overworked or inexperienced instructors in the front of the classroom with little to no support. For a university that is supposed to be built on collaboration there is far too much hierarchical red tape and ceremony to be productive.

job_title: Student Office Staff in Fort Collins, CO
pros: CSU generally provides a safe, inclusive environment for employees, especially if you are working in student affairs. There are a lot of protections for state classified employees. Current President Tony Frank does a great job of listening to the campus community and has a multicultural student advisory committee to share information with him about what it's like to be a marginalized student or staff member on campus.
cons: Sometimes it's a little too hard to get fired-- there are some bad employees and management has a hard time getting rid of them because of all the protections.

job_title: Social Media Coordinator in Fort Collins, CO
pros: The chance exists to get great professional experience as a student. Staff and faculty are interested in advancing your career, both professionally and as a student. Very accommodating with class schedules and extracurricular commitments
cons: Student employees are not paid very well, opportunities for advancement are slim. No benefits for the most part. SAHE staff are overworked and taken advantage of to some degree, although most are passionate about their jobs and thoroughly enjoy helping and connecting with students.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: CSU provided me an amazing graduate school experience. I was able to work as an instructor and attend classes while getting my Master's degree. I loved teaching and the professors I worked with were so intelligent and supportive. Fort Collins is one of the best places to live and the CSU campus is absolutely gorgeous. I wouldn't trade this graduate school experience for anything.
cons: Like any graduate level assistantship, student employees get paid little to nothing. The hardest part of working here was negotiating the workplace politics within the department. Every place has them, but these workplace politics were especially ruthless and brutal.

review_title: Loved Fort Collins but the PhD program does not prepare you well for life post-graduate school
job_title: Phd Student- Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Program in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Living in FoCo and meeting some great people
cons: 5 years of stress, hard work, and long hours.....and when you finish the degree ( if you are lucky enough to finish) job prospects are minimal. Many people failed or drop out each year, and I have a hard time of remembering people who actually enjoyed going to their respective labs. The PIs have all of the control, and basically own you for 5 to 7 years. You are just highly trained cheap labor to them, so they don't want to let you leave.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Beautiful area, great school, great students.
cons: This is a tight group who are not terribly open to anyone who either 1) is from another state, or, 2) did not graduate from CSU.  Sure, you can find a few staff members, here and there, who are not from CO or CSU grads - but the majority fit the description above, and they definitely like it that way, and they will look down their nose at anyone who doesn't fit the model..

review_title: Colorado State University, Fort Collins is  a great place to work with industry while doing your graduate school.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: You get to work with industry directly. All of the data required for your research comes from industry, so you are working with some real data and not any made up data. You also make good contacts with the people with industry as you directly work with them which helps while doing job search.
cons: Working with the industry on a research basis gets difficult sometimes as their requirements are continuously changing which might prolong your graduation by a semester or two.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Good benefits, predictable schedules, and job security. There are also some great perks, like being able to take up to 9 credits a year for free and use the campus recreation center at a big discount. Especially if you're still in your 20s working on campus can be a lot of fun.
cons: There's constant turnover of student staff, so being short-staffed and having inexperienced workers is an everyday occurrence. Old, constantly breaking equipment. And except for senior positions the pay is low, with "raises" which are less than the actual cost of living is going up.

job_title: Laboratory Research Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Fort Collins provides great scenery in being located just in front of the foothills of the Rocky Mountains. The weather is usually sunny and provides 4 great seasons. CSU allows undergraduates to actively participate in research and gives many undergraduates opportunities to become involved in extracurricular activities to help boost one's resume. Although the cost of tuition is rising, CSU is no MIT when it comes to cost of attendance.
cons: The name of Colorado State University doesn't exactly stand out to too many global employers. This leads to the unappreciative employers toward the hard working engineers who spend over 80 hours a week doing homework.

review_title: They suck. Thanks to Tony Frank, he ruined our institution. He is stupid for doing what he did down here. I am
job_title: Program Assistant III in Pueblo, CO
pros: They treat you like crap. Tony Frank fired great people and left us in a state of dysfunction that would rival what Hitler did.
cons: Tony Frank left idiots in charge of this insane asylum and they ran it into the ground, and now lay offs are rampant and have not stopped. We were promised years ago, that NO ONE would be laid off. NO ONE!

review_title: Not impressed with management at Colorado State University
job_title: International Student Advisor in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Autonomous working environment with a flexible schedule.
cons: The management is poor, with little supervision training. I often feel that they have no idea what they are doing or how to lead a staff or professionals. Most of the management in my area have been at CSU for a long time and don't seem to appreciate new blood or fresh ideas. They seem to be very closed to the idea of growth within the department and create a negative competitive environment.

job_title: Research Associate in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Great work environment.  The school is very supportive of research that is being done and works with employees at all levels of development. The benefits package is excellent.  They really look out for their employees.  The management is often very understanding of people if they want to take classes on campus too.  CSU is doing some really good work here.  I recommend everyone become a part of that.
cons: Grant management is difficult sometimes.  It is difficult to fund new or risky research with any leftover money.

job_title: Front Desk Manager in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Housing and Dining Services at Colorado State University employs a lot of students. Because of this, they are generally pretty good at working with class schedules. With in ResLife, the front desk managers, who make the schedules, are students themselves.
cons: Housing and Dining Services at Colorado State University recently went through some changes. They switched from having full time, salary employees being the front desk managers to having full time students run the front desks. This has caused some difficulties in the yearly transition processes as there will be a new manager every year to learn the ropes.

job_title: Research Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: CSU is a good research university, has a lot of availabilities and resources to support a wide range of projects, research, etc. Fort Collins is also a lovely place to live at, with beautiful mountain view, and lots of fun activities.
cons: I can't really think of any. CSU is a research university, so when it comes to research and lab work, it could be intense. Some of the buildings are quite old, with not updated equipment/facilities that might also be annoying. In general, CSU is still a really good place to work at.

review_title: Steady, easy workload, but vastly dependent upon your professor assignment.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros:
Flexible work hours, easy tasks, plenty of time for personal assignments. 
Exposure to professors and other students interested in similar vocations is a great opportunity.
cons: Compensation is ok to begin with, but doesn't increase with your experience or productivity. You will be slightly underpaid to begin with and vastly underpaid in the end. There are maximum jumps in pay per time period and certain positions or titles must be occupied for a specific time before you can advance.

job_title: Graduate Student in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Good pay as a graduate student. A great selection of up and coming professors. A wonderful place to be a graduate student in a nice town. Fort Collins offers a lot. There is also a new Chemistry Research building which is awesome
cons: The politics can be very brutal. I left due to department political reasons. CSU is also far from skiing places which is important for Colorado.

review_title: Solid foundation in facilities project management
job_title: Facilities Management Project Managemer Intern in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Working for Facilities at CSU was a pretty decent gig. I was able to work on a number of high-profile projects and really learned a lot about project management from the universities perspective.
cons: Some people in the management could be petty. At times work would go though a boom bust cycle, one week you'd be twiddling your thumbs, the next you'd be slammed with work.

review_title: This school offers diverse opportunities for involvement and research.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros:
The professors are knowledgeable and professional.
In terms of Civil Engineering classes, there are a wide variety of graduate classes that opened my eyes to areas within the field I had never known about as an undergraduate.
The materials testing facilities are adequate for most testing that would be conducted.
I had the chance to join local musical groups and join a good church during my time in Fort Collins.
cons: Computer labs are very bland and are often crowded and loud, and wi-fi is not always reliable.

review_title: CSU needs to work on accountability, diversity and inclusion
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Great location, fun town, nice campus.
cons: Tried really heard to y’all about inclusion and diversity. City and campus lacks diversity. Still has a long way to go to live up to all the talk about Principles of Community. There are some morale issues and lack of accountability in areas.

review_title: It's grad school. Either you've never been or you already know what I'm going to say.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Nice campus (aside from construction) and town, mostly kind and understanding professors, flexible work schedule.
cons:
This applies to any graduate program: Unless you really really really want to be a lifelong academic in a particular field and are awesome enough to obtain such a position then there is no good reason to join a phd program. It lasts forever. It pays peanuts (if you're lucky). It's tedious and depressing.  And it won't really leave you in a better position for a career out in the 'real world' than a shorter master's program, unless you take it upon yourself to learn skills that you think you'll want on your resume later, and if you can find the time to do that. 

Particular to CSU: Bureaucratic mess at times. Stuck in 20th century. All actions require forms to be printed, signed in triplicate, and faxed to relevant department. Websites are horrid and impossible. They messed up my tax forms several times. Parking is a nightmare. Campus is under constant construction for past few years. 

One more thing to consider about the income for a graduate student, if you are even so lucky to be in a field that has research stipends.  First of all the amount you are 'awarded' is very misleading A third of it will go towards tuition, which seems like a good deal the first two years that you take classes but after classes are over you will begin to wonder what you are still paying tuition for. What services is the school rendering for you at that point? Especially when every bit of equipment and software you use is paid for by some sort of government research grant. And when a research group is awarded a big grant from the NSF or NIH or whatever the school automatically gets a huge cut of that.  So after tuition you get your measly paycheck but you're not free yet. You must still pay the semester student fees which total over $1000 a year if you are a 'full-time student'. You could reduce these fees by only signing up for the bare minimum of credit hours but then you would not get the discount on health insurance, and plus you need a completely arbitrary amount of research credit hours to be able to graduate.

review_title: Generally a great company to work for
job_title: Assistant in Fort Collins, CO
pros: I have a fabulous boss, which always makes all the difference. The CSU campus is generally a great place to work - love the benefits.
cons: Some units have more issues than others. Luckily I'm not in one of those. During busy times work-life balance is hard, but my supervisor cares about that and finds ways to compensate for it.

review_title: A fair and well intended place to work
job_title: Program Manager in Fort Collins, CO
pros: CSU as a whole is working to increase efforts geared toward making people of color comfortable on campus and stay on campus. Typically the policies and processes are fair and supervisors have enough authority to make choices so you do not need to deal with the typical democracy of a large company. They give a good amount of PTO and benefits and make efforts to meet individual accommodations.
cons: It is a large university system. There are some strict rules that cannot bend. This can be difficult during personalized contexts.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fort Collins, CO

cons: Far enough away from Denver the professors don't get too many post-docs.  The professors in the college of Natural Sciences is oddly quite competitive amongst each other.

review_title: Great place and pretty good education depending on which lab you work in
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fort Collins, CO

Crowded with self-serving professors, the grad students have no choice but to quit their programs without a degree after putting in several years. The grievance addressal system favors professors and is managed by a cozy club of corrupt academics. 10-year graduate degrees are very common

- Need to break down silos between departments

review_title: Excellent experience satisfying for both future career ambitions as well as personal needs.
job_title: Archaeologicla Field Technician in Fort Drum, NY

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fort Collins, CO

Great town with high quality of life

Being sick with proof by doctors evaluation may not excuse slightly late work, which may result in termination without opportunity for appeal.

You may be subjecting yourself to trivial bureaucratic rulings which can have adverse impacts on your life and career.

It is likely your talent will be stifled rather than grown,

review_title: Very good place to work in

review_title: Great part time job to have while pursuing a degree
